newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Former Philippine rebel area said luring investors.
newsitem.headline: Former Philippine rebel area said luring investors.

text.p: A former war zone in the southern Philippines is currently attracting huge interest from investors, especially from Malaysia and Indonesia, a senior government official said on Saturday.

Presidential assistant for Mindanao Paul Dominguez said in a memorandum to President Fidel Ramos that a number of Indonesian conglomerates have already started operating in the former stronghold of Moslem rebels.
"Since the signing of the historic peace agreement between the government and the MNLF, there has been a definite surge in investor interest in Mindanao," Dominguez said.
The Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) ended its 24-year struggle for self-rule two months ago as it signed a peace agreement with the government.
MNLF chief Nur Misuari was recently elected as the governor of an autonomous area in Mindanao.

New Indonesian businesses include a ferry service operated by the Bakrie Brothers, a savings and development bank of the Dharmala Group, hotels by Bouraq Airlines and financial services from Lippo Bank.
Dominguez also said about 300 Malaysian businessmen recently accompanied Sabah's chief minister Yong Teck Lee on an investment mission to Mindanao.
Several memoranda of agreements have been signed including pacts on cattle breeding, trading of processed food and marine products, and construction projects.
Local businessmen have also expanded their operations in Mindanao with the establishment of new sugar mills, a grains terminal, and a softdrink manufacturing plant, Dominguez said.
